summary: Young Artemis Fowl finds himself in an epic battle against a race of powerful underground fairies.

reviews.content: It wasn't the best movie but hey it passed the time. It was pretty much boring at the start and it kept getting better than worse and in the end it was decent.

I'm on board with changing some things to adapt a book but this was just awful. The best part of the movie was Josh Gad and not by a whole lot.. It's just such a shame that from the fun book series, this is what they came up with..
This adaptation of "Artemis Fowl" somewhat ended up being a flat and souless take with rather stiff performances and a messy plot.
This is a horrible movie! It isn't anything like what it is in the books. I won't watch this movie ever again! 1/10

Though some good set and costume designs, this movie spits on its "source material" with a plot that makes no sense, flat characters, heaps of narration with no gravy and an absolute nightmare (the bad special effects in the scene do not help) of the most faithfully adapted scene, where Mulch tunnels into Fowl Manor.

"IT'S FEEDING TIME!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!"
. This blew my mind, not in a good way, but like like it turned my mind into troll snot and exploded it in a linen shop. It's not even so bad it's good. It's just bad.
In the words of Comic Book Guy from The Simpsons: "Worst. Disney movie. Ever!"
It was so bad it was funny.

for this film, the director deserves a pack of tomatoes in the face and a kick in the testicles.  from a terrible cast that ignores the book and omits the characterization of favorite characters to completely ignoring the idea.  apparently the director never read the book
I've read all the boots. This movie is Nottingham Else than an assault. Hated every Minute

Kenneth Branner is a great actor, but when it comes to actually making films, yikes, he should stick to the day job. How on Earth he managed to make Eoin Colfer's captivating writing so boring is incredible. I LOVE the books and I was so looking forward to seeing this film but I struggle to name anything that was good about it except maybe the depiction of haven city (although even there, the CGI is a bit weak). Terrible casting and wooden acting. Completely changed the storyline, so much that it would have been impossible to carry on the franchise into sequels. And the CGI was a bit low budget in places.
I really hope someone else eventually takes on these books and does them the justice they deserve as this adaptation is better best forgotten.
How was this made by Disney, the CGI and acting are both equally awful, the story is difficult to follow, and the characters are boring!
As someone who was obSESSED with these books as a kid, I could not help but feel personally attacked with how atrocious this so-called 'film' was. 0/10 enjoyment, 10/10 heartbreak

Completely unbearable. I could not continue watching this horrendous adaptation. With terrible actors, awful CGI, and a ridiculous plot, it could not be a worse movie. Unbelievably untrue to the book and so stupid. I hated it. I would have given zero stars if possible.

I hated this film so much, I had to stop watching the film in the middle to write this degrading review. It was very inaccurate to the book, and in all an utter pain to watch even a half. There were some degusting and vulgar senses that I could barely look AT! This movie should have been straight to DVD, or not even exist at all. Poor actors, poor quality, poorly reviewed, and most importantly portraited the characters in a god-awful way i can't even describe.
Worst movie I saw in some time.

I'm a fan of the books and barely made it 10 minutes into the movie. I've read the directors "justification" for completely changing the plot and character and see this is nothing but a money grab. If he believed his own reasoning he would have made a movie about a completely different story and character without using Artemis Fowl's well known name. He sucked all the fun out of it.
one of the worst, most confusing movies to come from Disney in a very long time...
Incredibly disrespectful to the books.
This is a really good movie to watch with family and friends. Its really dope!!!
The movie was almost nothing like the books except for a few scenes which i vividly remember. Kinda disappointed at this point. Fight scenes were good at least.
Way too many details crammed into one movie. They should have made it into a series instead. So many amazing actors wasted on this hot garbage.

Never read any of the books, so I cannot complain there.  This movie might be ok if I was maybe 12.  There are lots of bright lights and flashy CGI, but the plot is utter nonsense and full of plot holes.  What the characters do seems arbitrary and mostly pointless. The world-building, while flashy, was weaker than even Percy Jackson.  And while there were no real write home performances, the kid playing Fowl just came off like a plank of wood reading lines... and I am not sure why any of this film makes him a criminal mastermind.
On the up side, I liked the Holly character, even if she made dumb decisions.  And the movie was at least imaginative I suppose.
The only thing this movie has in common with the books is the name of the book and the character names. Other than that it's absolute garbage that destroys everything great the books envisioned.

I genuinely do not know why this movie was made. The story is generic and bland. It fails to make me care about or like the characters. Some of the dialog is abysmal. This movie is one of the worst out there.
this film... it's so strange...and the fidelity to the book can go to hell
I wish I could of put 0 stars for dis it was definitely not Morbtacular.

While all hope isn't lost for this franchise of potential, and possible sequel will have a tough time proceeding with the story that has started with a confusing plot that seems to have separated itself from it's novel. While the characters are likable, a few comedic moments hit the target, and the acting is on point, this movie is quite the unexpected failure from what could have been an ideal start to the next Harry Potter-like franchise.

Visually appealing with a good cast but their talents were not utilized to their fullest. I really wanted to like this movie but the script left much to be desired.  The elements of story and character were left pretty much unexplored so things did not tie together in a meaningful way, It just didn't work for the most part.  Even so, I enjoyed this film though it was just 125 million dollars of "ehh."
Quite bad. Even children can't connect with the character sketches.

First of all, if there were a 0 star rating, this is the embodiment of it. The plot seems to make no sense at all, and as a person that has read the books, it just angered me. Also, the child actor, Ferdia Shaw has no potential in the movie at all, no offense. I mean, not just him. Every actor in this movie just sounds like they are literally, reading off a script. If this was in the big screen, people would ask for refund. It's a waste of time, and I'm pretty sure I can make a better movie with the same budget. In short, no plot, no emotion, no potential, no chemistry and no sense. The biggest part of the books is that the Fowls are criminal masterminds. Artemis Fowl movie? The only thing that makes this movie a criminal mastermind is that they fooled us and robbed our money, and time. Shame on the director and actors. Lead role for Artemis Fowl is absolutely hideous.

0/10 Movie
Basically a Rotten Piece of Sh**

This is a great movie , lots of detailed information of all the different characters. 
Ireland is beautiful, this was a great choice . 
I have seen this movie several times and I love it every time . Friends I share this movie with all agree . I do not know any information about trolls , fairies etc what if I did I guarantee you I would have a different view on this movie!
I really hope there is a sequel ! My ADHD does not allow me to Read books and remember a lot of information , so …movies work  best .
Thanks 
Must watch !!!
one Tip: Read the Books instead.

I do not think that the director read the book before making this film. One of my favourite characters - Commander Root, a purple faced angry man, was changed to a woman? Now im all for including females in movies, however, its not like a main character wasnt already a female (Captain Holly Short). The whole reason Holly is special in the books is that she is the First ever female LEP officer they have had. Part of the story is her dealing with discrimination and overcoming it.

As for their portrayal of Artemis... I can barely comment it was almost like they tried to make this character the opposite of the books portrayal. I suspect that the director of this film skimmed the first few pages, saw the line 'Artemis's search had begun two years previously when he first became interested in
surfing the Internet.' on page 12, and decided that Artemis should be an athletic person who likes Surfing....
Absolutely outrageous.

A young boy must use his magic and preternatural manor buddies to stop a hooded figure from taking over mankind.  This live-action Disney flop borrows banal fantasy themes from J.K. Rowling books and polishes them over with unimpressive CGI, crappy characters and a stale plotline.

It didn't match the first book, it was more like a mash-up between the first and second book, but I thought it was a good way to portray the story on film.
It was slightly frustrating that the conflict between Holly and Artemis was resolved REALLY quickly, but I can see that the original would have drawn out the story much longer.  The point of the movie was slightly different, meaning the relationship between the two main characters was different.

I'm not sure I would have paid to see it on the big screen but it was a great way to pass the time while sick at home.  

I'm looking forward to the sequel.
This is one of the greatest movies of all time. It's got everything action magic suspense drama and these boneheads at Rotten Tomatoes only gave it 8% which is absolute bullshit

They spent a lot of money to make a movie where bright lights and words happen. Also, there's a kid in it who thinks he's hot stuff and everyone agrees with him, but he never does jack squat, then the movie ends.

Based on the novel of the same name by Eoin Colfer, a young boy must rescue his kidnapped father with the help of some unusual characters. This film was delayed in release for extensive reshoots and the COVID-19 pandemic and eventually released on Disney+. This is just a bad film and might be a great example for film students to see on how not to make a film. There is way too much narration, from exposition to describing character motivations and introductions. Character interactions are brief, unless there is an action scene. There are significant acting irregularities, like the actors had to come back to the character after a long hiatus for reshoots. Spatial awareness is non-existent as characters jump to random locations. Josh Gad did get a few laughs out of me as a positive. Save yourself the trouble and avoid this film.

I have read the Artemis Fowl book series 3 times now. I've been waiting for years for a movie to come out. I wish that this movie would be deleted because it shows no respect for the books. I could say this movie was living nightmare, and that would be an understatement. Disney lost a great opportunity of remaking the the book series of Artemis fowl to a movie series. I hope they can redo this movie and make it like the first Artemis fowl book.
it did not make sense it was very boring they did not tell much about the father or any of the characters it was one of my least favorite movies i have watched
Though it had structural problems it was much better than the critics claim. I would love to see a sequel and maybe a full series.
A reasonably entertaining production. As with most adaptations of books they tend to fall a bit short of the book, but entertaining enough.
artemis fowl is infinity percent fowl with its embarrassing performances and lack of story

I really enjoyed this one despite the poor ratings it received as I thought it was a very interesting story about an imaginary world below us. I hope they continue on with the franchise and create the next story installment soon.

I will start by saying I didn't read the book. That being said I really like serlockion stories and this delivers spectacularly. The humor was amazing, which is a problem I'm starting to see show up in more movies lately. I can't wait to see what the second movie has in store. I'm Split on the trailer. It didn't make me really want to see the movie but if it would have revealed anything more I think it would have ruined everything. I will say though I'm baffled at how low a score rotten tomatoes gave the movie. Definetly in my top 20 movies.

Fanciful, fun, fantastic fable full of fairies and folklore! What more could you ask for. I'd never heard of the books before but the movie is certainly highly entertaining. After the boredom of the meandering Dune last night, Artemis Fowl was a refreshing treat.

When I first watched this movie, I cried. For a while. I had waited nearly two decades for this and I wish I was still waiting. It would have been better than witnessing my favorite universe sentenced to Disney lock-up, never to be remade into something worth adoring like the books. Eoin Colfer is a genius and it broke my heart to see his beautiful, intricate world and multi-faceted, compelling characters be relegated to ninety minutes of disjointed, inaccurate, and frankly, dumbed-down, House of Mouse corporation twaddle. It is equally heartbreaking to read reviews of parents who say, "I don't know why these people are giving the movie such bad reviews. My kids loved it!" You are doing a disservice to the incredible world that is Artemis Fowl by allowing them to think that oversimplification of a film is all there is. This is not a fair representation of the stories I grew up with and I canceled my Disney+ account because of it. Go read the books.
Terrible movie, changed everything from the books, even minor details, for no reason
There's nothing cool about this movie. . . This movie is just honestly a big waste of time to me.

Similar to the books or not, this is not a great adaptation even as a standalone movie. It suffers from confusing and rushed plot points, lack of character development, no chemistry whatsoever. Scenes and sequences are stitched together with no continuity. Too much exposition during the beginning, and too little explanation during the later half of the movie. The villain is confusing and serves no purpose. Jarring music scores are inserted in an unsuccessful attempt to induce emotions. The only saving grace are the special effects and cinematography.

Having loved Disney films, I know the company values great writing and emotionally fulfilling stories more than anything else. Unfortunately, this movie doesn't even have a functioning storyboard.

I read the YA fantasy book series almost two decades back and remember enjoying it, so was excited about the movie, sadly this was a disappointment. Don't think it follows the source material, the plotting and writing are really lacking. Felt they pack too much in too short a time and none of it significant, the characters and fantasy world fails to pull the audience in.  More time was spent in long-drawn chaos action sequence than exploring the lore of mystical Irish fairy tale which made the book series so much fun.

This film shouldn't exist. This is barely a movie for me. It feels like $125 million was just thrown into this mess and no one was really sure what to do with it. Disney eventually decided to dump their tumor onto Disney plus and I'm sure they've already lost a lot of money here before releasing the film. I've would've been happier if they never released it and Disney just abandoned the movie altogether. There's so much wrong here that I could write my own book on how not to adapt a fantasy novel for the big screen.
My kids enjoyed this movie. They want a sequel. Sorry there are so many haters. It was fun to watch.
Animation is good, but camera and story are absolutly boring shit. 98 Minutes of wasted life time
Disgrace to the book series. They tried to cram all 7 books into one movie, and failed miserably. Messed up so many parts, and included random parts that never happened and never would in the books.
I make it one of my favorite movies right now.  It's a movie that made me cry.  The characters are very well acted.  It would be a shame if I didn't see the next part

I would be okay with the movie if the only problem was that it was different from the books. I promise, I would be. BUT THAT IS NOT THE ONLY  PROBLEM. Pretty much every main character is unlikeable, and if they aren't it's because of the actor. I won't be surprised when Disney receives a lawsuit from The Power-Rangers asking for their villain back. Also, I'm still confused as to how the movie received a PG rating with that disgusting "mulch-eating-dirt" scene. Just because a movie is targeted at children doesn't mean you don't have to try.
They ruined a book I loved from my childhood. The main character was not even close to the one from the book.

Genuinely upsetting. Having read all of the books more times than I can count, I was SO excited for this film to be released. And I was devastated within the first 30 seconds of it starting. Artemis Fowl would now have been caught dead on a surf board. Or even near the sea! What the hell!? I got drunk, to get through it, and then I cried a little bit. The books are still read semi regularly, but we are going to pretend that the movie doesn't exist.

it clearly was supposed to be multiple parts because the story is just so janky, now I have not read the books but it's clear as day that the movie's plot just feels rushed it really needed to be at least 2 parts because getting the dad so quickly is just bad writing and the people who wrote and approved the script must have been mentally disabled at the point that they could barley function on there own.

The only thing they really kept from the books was the character names and an extremely vague similarity to the books plot. If you're a fan of the books just do yourself a favor and skip this movie because it is some of the worst content I have seen Disney produce. 
It looks like everything was shot in one take and the script seems like someone read the book once and then wrote a rough draft in a couple of hours. The writing and delivery of the lines is so wooden and awkward and just a lazy and terrible attempt at reworking things from the book that didn't need to be changed. 
If they had literally just copy pasted the plot and lines from the book this movie would have been 100 times better off, even if the acting had been poor.
If I had to guess I would say Disney thought the best way to maximize profit for this movie was to not care at all and just spend as little time and effort on this as possible. If a sequel ever somehow gets produced I will just skip it and wait for reviews to make sure it's not a travesty like this movie.

I am 35, have been a huge fan of the books since reading the "Artemis Fowl" when I was about 17. I love the content and story building, the constant character development and excitement each book brought to life. However this movie does not do it justice. It is as bad in my opinion as Last Air Bender. It had no business being put on the big screen with so much changes. The actors/actresses should be ashamed of how horribly they portrayed the characters of the books. Nothing about this movie made me feel at all like I was in the book again. It did not at all follow character development and build up that Eoin Colfer so wonderfully imagined. This film does not even deserve a half star.
A deeply disappointing adaption of Eoin Colfer's fantastic books.
This was a nightmare. How did this ever get made? No relation to the books in the slightest. I literally made an account just to rate this movie.
Nothing necessarily wrong happened here, but nothing necessarily right did either.  Just completely mediocre, with close to nothing to offer.

Completely lacking consistency, this absolute dumpster fire of a movie made me feel rage like I've never felt before. As a book lover, this is the worst book-to-movie adaptation I've ever had the horror of watching.
Too many shortcuts that Hollywood has took. Especially with multiple unwarranted plot points straying away from the source material. Same thing happen in the Percy jackson and the olympians films.
A very bad boring movie. Nicely shut, well produced score, good special effects and good actors. All it needed was a decent script, like so many other American movies theese days.
Yeah, it's pretty awful.
This was a disasterpiece.

The story seemed to give Artemis too many wins and not enough time to flesh out each of the characters leaving the overall pace of the movie feeling rushed. The animations during the "time freeze" parts were pretty cool.

If I could give this movie negative stars, I would. They completely changed the story and usurped the name of Artemis Fowl. I hate it so much, they did a horrible job. Please do not watch this movie or give it more money. I hope you're proud Disney, I hope this movie burns in the fiery pits of hades for all eternity. They completely changed the premise. Artemis IS NOT the good guy, he is an anti-hero who has to gain his morals throughout the series. Do not claim you made an Artemis Fowl movie, all you have done is ruin childhoods and misrepresent a wonderful story. You didn't 'make it palatable to younger audiences' you made a different story, with different characters. Though I do admit the designs for haven and Fowl manor were quite lovely, you still completely changed a story that was already wonderful and full of a diverse cast, also you made Holly white. Holly is described as having "nut-brown skin" that's whitewashing. I have so many problems with this film and could go on for pages, But I won't subject any readers to that. But please don't watch this movie. Its such a dissapointment.
One thing I have to say about it, worst movie of 2020.
The acting was laughable. I can't believe they produced, shot, edited and still let this film hit the "theaters".

This movie is the the worst Disney movie I have ever experienced by a long shot, nothing makes sense. Every minute of the movie I find another glaring plot hole in this mess of a film. If you have find yourself with some spare time don't spend it watching this disaster of a movie adaption.

OMIGOD!!!! ITS SOOO AWFUL
ITS NOTHING LIKE THE BOOK EXCEPT THE NAMES 
OH AND BTW 
ARTEMIS WOULDNT BE CAUGHT DEAD IN A TSHIRT AND JEANS
The movie was a good start for more movies of the kind. It doesn't do a good job of being a stand alone movie though. It is however decent and worth a watch.

I haven't read any of the other reviews, and I had never heard of this movie prior to my 12 year old daughter wanting to watch it for the second time.  It has creepy voices and some characters, but over all this is age appropriate for 12+ or earlier that have experienced worse.

In my opinion, this movie is worth 4 if not 5 stars.  I'm a fan.  I could go into the nuances and character building (Holly, Olaf) and fantasy story line....  Wow.  Great movie, I highly recommend!
Movie is fun and a little silly, but entertaining. Also, for children.
good work by the actors but the film was horrendous

Here we go again with the kids acting like adults. I get it, Artemis is smart. But DANG. It is just frustrating in this movie. I feel bad for Kenneth Branagh. It is definitely not his best film. If you want to watch a movie where kids don't act like arrogant grown-ups, watch the Harry Potter series.

This movie really doesn't deserve its intense criticism. Its visually beautiful, showcases talented actors, and is utterly unique. True, it bares only a passing resemblance to the books, which unsurprisingly leaves fans frustrated. But if taken as its own story, the film is more than worthy of praise.

The only criminal mastermind in this movie is Disney. Given its abundant source material, it is largely unimaginative and provides nothing that you would expect from the cleverness and humor from the Artemis Fowl books. Easily one of the greatest letdowns since "The Last Airbender".
worst movie I have watched in a while. why change the story so much from the books!!!!
This is the most rushed movie I have ever watched... I could swear that 90% of the scenes were actually fast forwarded

I wanted to like this movie, I truly did. I am a huge fan of the books and I believe this movie didn't even try to do them justice. Within the first 5 minutes, they give away Butler's first name, which is a huge plot point in a later book. Mulch is talking to human authorities about fairies, and Artemis Sr is the reason Artemis Jr begins searching for them? Butler is not of Eurasian descent but is of African descent. I'm fine with the director's decision in that regard, however, I disagree wholeheartedly with the decision to have him wear those horrendous blue contacts.  Furthermore, Butler is supposed to be athletically massive and jacked. Nonso Anozie is a great actor, but for all his size, he cuts a portly, unimposing figure. I will eventually go back and suffer through the rest of this movie. If you are a fan of the books, my advice is to not even attempt to watch the movie.

absolutely terrible misses all the good parts of the book while trying to jam an entire book into a rather short movie. was exceptionally boring with terrible writing. tries to compensate with cgi but way overdoes it.

Cut out the last 5-10 minutes of the movie and the rating goes up about one star but anyone who read the books would feel betrayed by this movie. (heck anyone who didn't read the books would still feel betrayed for their loss of time). I kind of get the feeling that owen colfer spent the last 20 years trying to get this movie made then finally he gave up and said screw it i'll give it to disney so then at least some-Thing will get made. Sadly, he should've known better. I only wonder if Disney let colfer watch the movie before it got released...
This ruined the books for me, holy cow. Nothing in this movie was worthwhile. Every lead actor was flat and the cgi just destroyed every memory of the book.

I want you to imagine the entire Harry Potter franchise, amazing movies, and even better books, cut into 1hour and 55mins, including the scrolling text. 

It's a fucking joke and I feel so violated. No fucking way you wanted this movie to succede.

Well not the greatest but certainly not the worst either. It's good to spend the time with your niece or nephew but i wouldn't watch this by myself. Movie is filled with logical gaps and unexplained lore that left me scratching my head. Visuals are pretty decent and definetly screams that a lot of the budget went to visuals than screenplay.  All and all, "meh" movie, children would love it.

The movie takes an original and unique novel with well written and interesting characters and transforms it into a generic YA film filled with tired clichés and lazy writing. As an adaptation it bears little resemblance beyond the superficial to the books it is based on, and is a poor movie in its own right. It feels disjointed and smashed together, as if it was thrown together in a hurry without a lot of thought. The acting is mediocre to poor, with even big name actors putting in a half hearted performance - you can tell that they know how badly this was going to flop and regretting signing those contracts. Even buckets of gaudy CGI can't cover up the dumpster fire that is this crude adaptation of a classic work of fiction. Whether you're a fan of the books or not, you're better off giving this film a miss.

I recently reread all 8 of the Artemis Fowls books, afterwards, I decided against my better judgement to give this movie a chance, what a horrible mistake. This movie is little more than an incoherent mess that ruins everything that made the books great in favor of a "plotline" that makes no sense, and characters that either are nothing like their book counterparts, or even near opposite, such as butler, who acts almost opposite how he acts in the books, and Artemis changing from an actual nefarious child genius that's a real threat to his enemies, to a little kid that makes quips sometimes that are supposed to make him seem smart but convinces no one. Seriously, read the books and do not give this movie a second thought, unless you want the books almost ruined for you, it was that bad.

To be short and clear, this movie is bad.
It feels something like Spy Kids and Sharkboy and Lavagirl, but aim lower. The plot is just boring, there's no engagement. I will not say that the characters had a bad development, they didn't have any developments at all. There's good actors in this movie, like Dench, but I honestly don't know what they're doing. The dialogues are boring and unnatural, feels like the lines of a school play. Some nice effects, but they don't add much giving the rest of the elements exposed. To be honest, this whole movie just feels off, I'm very disappointed.

It was probably best Disney put this movie right on Disney+ instead of going to theaters. It’s a bomb. The movie does boost a lot of special effects which are decent trolls, elves, fairies but that’s all the movie has to offer. The acting especially from the main character is horrible. The movie structure is all over the place and I felt like some scenes were missing and a very poor narrative. It probably looks good on paper but the final product is just a mess.
Everything about this absolutely incomprehensible clunker is as hollow as it's version of the Earth.
Artemis Fowl is a visually fascinating experience with where story and character falls short, despite it being a good romp overall.

I wasn't even looking for the movie, it's not the funniest thing I've ever seen but helped to comfort my insomnia. I never read the books.
Feeling the same level of frustration after watching Percy Jackson adaptation.

Good ideas, a awesome universe. But so underestimate.

I watched Artemis Fowl. And that "movie" is probably the worst movie I have seen in a long time.  Usually, when a movie is based on a book tanks, you can fall back on the book, but this movie was so bad that it makes me actively not want to read the book. Of course, I am exaggerating a tad but the movie is that bad.  It was uninspiring and almost like no one actually cared about what they were making.  The acting wasn't the best but I don't really blame the actors. The kids tried and the adults collected a paycheck, but that was it.

Boring and trivial, badly managed times, and situations that happened without a valid reason, almost embarrassing.  You perceive the cut of some scenes that perhaps would have explained better what happens in the film, too bad because it could have been very interesting.

Shares nothing with the book series apart from the name. The books are interesting and entertaining in the same vein as 'Harry Potter' - this film is NOT based on the books, some of the characters remain but they're sanitized into bland, unengaging dross.
Avoid.

After reading all eight of the books, I understand why they had to change some things up. When you read all of the books the movie is actually quite impressive! If you have not read at least the first and second book please do not write a review as you may not understand why they changed some things. When you think of the original plot the new one is not that much different.

Awful, completely destroyed the world building I loved in the books. I knew from the trailer it was going to be bad but this was worse than I thought. Broke my heart 3 mins in. The characters and their motivations were UNRECOGNIZABLE. I really hope anyone who watches this movie will give the books a chance. There is no comparison.
20 minutes into the movie the are enough to realize that it's one of the worst Disney failures in recent history.
this film is a mess with the lead character being strange and annoying, the action not memorable and a waste of a perfectly good cast. the story is also quite bland.

I've read and loved the books. The pale irish boy with his scary vampiric grin who can frighten adults with his intelligence. The boy who won the chess world championship under a synonym. The boy who is so driven of his idea about the fairy folk underground that he has everything planned through. 
I've seen nothing of this in the movie. NOTHING. 
The whole plot changed and is such a flustercuck of things happening in the books... I haven't felt so much disappointment in years, if ever at all. The Cast choice is bad which affects the whole background of the MAIN CHARACTERS !!! Butler is discribed as fitting in everywhere because of his eurasian heritage, Root is now portayed as a woman which destroys Holly's story as the first female LEP officer, deleting her mishaps and the pressure on her as a character. 
Artemis' mother is dead, not hiding in her bedroom because of Opal's hypnosis. And the biggest "wtf-moment" was when Juliet Butler was shown as the 12 year old niece of Domovoi Butler, who in the books was his sister, a wrestling fan doing "MMA" herself with a jade Ring in her long Ponytail, which she uses in fight. 
Why didn't they just stick to the books and made it an awesome movie ?!!!
This movie was just terrible. Horrible writing, acting, production across the board. I hope they don't make a sequel.
What a abomination of man kind
I read the books and understood the changes made to it. It was very well done!
This is a travesty of a movie. When i was younger i dreamed of an Artemis fowl movie, now im just glad i grew up so child me wouldnt be crushed by this THING.

Saying it is an adaptation of the book series, is a bit of an understatement. It's absolute garbage. I mean, it barely utilizes the names and places, but the story is completely different, in a bad way. There's no structure in this adaptation, the story makes no sense. An most of all, they change the characters completely. I mean Artemis surfing? A huge disappointment.

I thought the movie was fast paced, entertaining for both kids and adults.  The sets and action were very well done. In so drastically losing the essence of the character, the film, directed by Kenneth Branagh, exposes a startling lack of imagination. Artemis Fowl's genius is slashed in half, and his evil is watered down to childish desperation. There is no room for him to grow since the good and bad sides are clearly marked, and any greyness in his character is deftly wiped away. While the film has excellent production quality, tiny pixels do not, in any way, compensate for lazy characters. Why could the filmmakers not retain the evil protagonist of this brilliant book franchise? Why does nuance make them so uncomfortable? How could an entire cast and film crew agree to taking a unique narrative, hacking it down with a machete, and then remoulding it so it can fit into a gigantic dumpster fire of a feature. Oh yea, we'll keep the name and market it as the official adaption of the book. Then we'll change the characters the plot, and every single detail so that the only part of the movie that even remotely resembles the books is the names and the F'ing title. This movie is a standalone piece of absolute garbage. I am in absolute awe that this Director had the balls to oversee a complete rewrite of the entire works of Eoin Colfer. Kenneth Branagh is either a terrible human being or a completely out of touch half wit. In either case he should never work in Hollywood again.

I really like the first book. I'm not saying it's good, but I like it. The concept of a child "criminal mastermind" and the explanation of the lore is fascinating. Colfer, the author, is not great at world building. He's very character and dialogue focused which is why I was excited for a movie. It would put things into context and eliminate all the pointless dialogue. Well, it didn't. In fact, ALL it contained was pointless dialogue, and there was still no context. I read an online review saying someone must have based the screenplay on a wiki summary. I disagree. I think whoever wrote the screenplay read the series very carefully. He or she would have had to in order to make everything and everyone the exact opposite of what it is/they are. He or she would have to be very familiar with the whole series in order to make sure nothing accurate got into the movie. I watched this movie twice. The first time I got so annoyed that it took me two days to finish. It took everything interesting about the books, crumpled it up, ate it, and promptly threw it back up. I watched it a second time, all at once, as if I'd never read the books. The second time was worse. It is an objectively bad movie. The script was nonsense; there wasn't really a progression of events, just scenes put together; and there was little to no explanation of ANYTHING. To all those who never read the books and liked this movie: didn't you wonder why Holly spoke English even though her name was written in Gnomish on her helmet? Didn't you even wonder what Gnomish was?
As for the characters, they wrote Holly as a tantruming child instead of a level-headed officer. They made Butler the comedic relief instead of a strong and silent soldier. And Artemis...liked being outside. Kenneth had what was clearly a talented core cast (Ferdia, Lara, Nonso) and he did everything wrong with them. They barely had any screen time together, and in general. The Artemis Fowl books were made for movie adaptations. They have so much pointless dialogue, scenes that could easily be shortened or cut, and room for artistic interpretation that they are basically a filmmakers dream. Yet somehow, even with all that leeway, Kenneth Branagh still managed to ruin this movie.

Oh, watching this film made me furious. As a fan of the original material, I sometimes found myself wondering if the people who made the movie had ever read the actual books. 
        First, the good things. The visuals are impressive, and the music outstanding. This is why I did not give this movie a 1/10 and instead gave it a 2. But neither of these can compensate for literally everything else dragging the movie down.
        The story is butchered horribly and rushed, leaving no emotional value behind. The acting is ok in some spots, like Shaw, who is good for a child actor. But Holly is stripped of her original plotline and replaced with a weaker irreverent one. The fairies are twisted to be allies, while in the books they are Artemis' targets. Artemis' father is completely unnecessary as he is supposed to be dead in the books. And Artemis' mother, who has one of the best arcs and actions in the book, is tossed out, which weakens the family story even more. Josh Gad is one of the worst possible choices for Mulch, who loses all of his charm and sarcastic humour. Butler has snow white hair and eyes, which makes no sense and is very distracting. Foaly has no personality whatsoever and the other elves are scrapped entirely. Commander Root is no longer intimidating in the slightest, and is played by Judi Dench. JUDI. DENCH. ROOT IS A GUY AND A LARGE PART OF HIS STORY REVOLVES AROUND HIM BEING A GUY. The villain is plucked from the second movie, made to look and sound "evil" (which fails hilariously) and is thrown in. She then proceeds to do almost nothing except kidnap a single person. This means that Artemis is technically just as evil as her, and this is not helpful in making the villain seem threatening. A random infinity-gauntlet style object called the Aculos is added, and is completely random and ill-defined. Plot points from the second book are added to the mix and confuses as to which book the movie is trying to retell. 
        In summary, Artemis Fowl is an absolute dumpster fire of a film, disregarding everything that made the books great in the first place, and even though there is a setup for a sequel at the end of the movie, it won't be necessary. This movie joins Percy Jackson in the realm of god-awful book adaptations. 2/10, do not watch.

I'm finally watching this GOD AWFUL Artemis Fowl film.
If you're not at all interested in an over the top impromptu review of this film... look away now... because this is about to be a self-indulgent, irrationally angry, absolutely dumb review but my god it needs it.
As a massive fan of the books, I was as excited about it becoming a film as I was when Harry Potter made the transition when I was younger. Are film adaptations perfect? NEVER! There are far too many rich details in the literary arts to capture on screen... and so we accept compromise and change to narratives and characters either physical or behavioural, especially if it has some wider societal relevance. 
That being said... WHAT THE ACTUAL HELL WERE THESE MORONS THINKING!? It's like they read the book and then thought... "Yeah let's just change every single thing about it and not make casting decisions based on the characters but instead just randomly cast some popular names... apart from the lead character, let's cast the most generic white kid even if he can't act".

Artemis Fowl - Ill mannered 12 year old, misfit evil-genius, criminal mastermind who is searching for his missing father, has to care for his grief ridden mother, while also being responsible for replenishing the family fortune - "Nah let's make him a soft, extremely mediocre, surfboarding normal kid who just has to have a bunch of memories flash up in random order... also let's make him nice so that kids everywhere can relate to being a good kid"

Artemis Fowl Sr - Missing presumed dead criminal mastermind turned legitimate eco-entrepreneur with Mrs Fowl driven mad by grief - "Nah let's make him alive, kill Mrs Fowl, make him obsessed with fairy life and have Colin Farrell play him because he's a well known Irish actor. Oooh and let's have him be a misunderstood, misrepresented hero who has only ever done good in the world because kids need a role model"

Butler - A purely professional bodyguard/butler, Butler's have always guarded Fowls, are trained from childhood in martial arts and are forbidden from revealing their names to their subjects. He is tall, bald, intimidating and fiercely loyal and will ONLY be referred to as Butler - "Nah, let's say he takes offence at being called Butler [presumably because they chose to cast a black man and wanted to avoid the connotations of calling a black man a butler] and let's make him the most dull, uninteresting, unimpressive bodyguard you've ever seen... and let's give him grey hair and blue eyes for no real reason... oh and make his sister his niece"

Commander Root - A gruff, no-nonsense exterior with a heart of gold, Root is a badass old timer with a handlebar moustache, rosey cheeks, a constantly lit cigar and a "get it done" attitude. A military veteran among the fairy kind and someone that will still get dirty and scrap with the youngsters throughout the coming stories, Root is the epitome of 'old school hard' - "Nah let's cast Dame Judy Dench"...

DAME JUDY F***ING DENCH! I agree that if you're going to change a character from their description, then Root is the character to do it with but WHAT?! The guy that played Butler would've made a waaaay better Root and then you could've called him BUTLER!
JUDY CAN'T WALK! LET ALONE FIGHT! You want an example of an actor that does similar roles who would've been a casting choice that made sense? SIGOURNEY WEAVER!

Mulch Diggums - A fairy dwarf with a gruff voice and a nonchalance for flatulence - "Nah let's make him a 'giant dwarf'... but let's also have him say that to actual dwarfs so that you know actual dwarfs exist in this universe... oh and let's have him be the film's narrator even though he's not actually been around for 3/4s of the story... oh and let's have Josh Gad play him because he's known for being gruff, dirty and unpleasant right?... oh and let's just make it seem like he's super super important even though he's a background character"

AND DON'T EVEN GET ME STARTED ON THE STORY! They took the first book... combined it KIND OF with the next 3 books... and over complicated EVERY SINGLE ASPECT of the story. You lose any coherence throughout the narrative, you have no hook and you get zero connection to the characters.

Juliet who is Butler's sister/niece turns up randomly throughout the film... there's no real thought to it... just... here she is... now she's gone... here she is again!
Artemis is portrayed as a dumb kid... zero evidence of the high IQ he has other than all of the other characters going,
"oh it's Artemis Fowl, SEND EVERYONE".
The performances were bloody atrocious too! The main kid that played Artemis SUUUUCKED!

It's so incredibly bad that I legitimately wish someone could be fired for it. Is that bad to say? Yeah probably. FIRE KENNETH BRANAGH from all directing in the future. He literally butchered everything to do with what is among the greatest YA franchises ever written. 
All that budget was clearly spent on VFX, rather than on actual script-writing. GAH!

Well, this was a loss that Disney certainly benefited from cutting, because this movie is dead on arrival. I only read the first book. It was fine. Had a unique idea and interesting world-building but personally, I prefer Rick Riordan. I think it's because of Eoin Colfer's writing style - short but that's only because the chapters are really long - that I never really got into the books. But while the Percy Jackson movies can still be enjoyed just fine if taken as standalone movies, the Artemis Fowl movie is an incoherent mess. Fans are guaranteed to be pissed at the characterisations whilst people who've never read the books will be confused as to why this good-natured kid is acting like a bad guy when the movie presents him as much more unambiguously heroic than in the first book. Hell, I suspected that something was amiss when it was announced an understandably grumpy-looking Judi Dench would be playing Commander Root. Wasn't it the whole point in the book that Holly was the first female LEPrecon officer? As for Artemis himself...this poor, poor child actor is clearly trying to make the character work but bad direction and a worse screenplay means that, if Disney bothers to release the movie on Blu-ray, we'll get a blurb referring to him as "...the next Jake Lloyd" which anybody who knows about his acting career is aware that that's not a compliment. The visuals? They're fine. It looks like a video game at times and other times downright terrifying but the hidden world does look decent. If you ask me, Josh Gad was the closest thing this movie had to a saving grace. He's not terrific and his attempts at doing a Batman impression are laughable at best but hey, nice to see that Olaf seems to be the only one aware that this movie is a textbook example of how NOT to adapt a beloved series. I even personally think this type of movie is outdated nowadays. This movie would be right at home in the 2000's and early 2010's when literature-based fantasy movies were at their prime but in 2020, I'd expect an Artemis Fowl adaptation to be a TV show. Yeah, I dunno, I ran out of legitimate reasons to complain and just decided "you don't belong in this era of movies full of superheroes, live-action remakes and shared universes". My point is, that Artemis Fowl is an absolutely horrendous adaptation that makes no sense neither as an adaptation nor on its own merits and is definitely one of Disney's largest misfires. Smart move banishing this movie that takes place around one big house to a streaming service so that families have something new to watch during this stay-at-home challenge that's been going on for months now. Leave your home and get sucked to a whole new world where you spend time in somebody else's home. Don't worry, guys, we'll make it through this pandemic.

I had only read the first book of the series before diving into this dull experience, and even I could tell they were way off the source material. We've seen success with staying close to the book from films like Harry Potter, Hunger Games, and Holes, so why not continue that train and trust the audience is smart enough to fill in details without the movie directly explaining the problem so transparently.  The layers of character development in the book are replaced entirely with surface details fabricated for the characters. Here's an extreme example: In the book, Artemis Fowl is supposed to be pictured as a heartless, driven anti-hero, but we know he also has a weakness for his insane mother because of their interactions throughout the first book. In the movie, the mother is replaced with the missing father, and the mother has passed away! The film also took the opportunity to introduce Artemis Fowl's origin story before the real adventure begins, and that in itself left no imagination for the audience to decipher the situation themselves as the thrilling hunt for mythical creatures starts. I am especially disappointed with Holly's appearance and her relationship with Root. Her backstory and why she gets captured by Fowl changes too; instead of having to do the moon ritual on the surface, she disobeys orders and goes to search for her missing father. I could be wrong, but the author describes her with "nut-brown" skin, and there was controversy amongst fans about that for years after as she was depicted by fans, comic books, and then the film with much paler skin in comparison to nut-brown. Also, Root is a woman as well in the film.... it takes the whole dynamic of Holly being one of the few females in uniform away when the hard-ass boss is also a woman too. They never mention the gender problem in the film like they do in the book, which I guess is a sign of the times. Some could argue that showing sexism in a professional workforce setting like policing could be revealing to younger viewers that woman are looked down on in someway, when they should just be able to see that men and woman can work equally without any discrimination. However, I think getting rid of that in the film did just the opposite. It's not as if that doesn't exist anymore (discrimination based on race or gender) in real life, though we do not see it as often, so to just take that part out entirely also made it seem like Holly has nothing to prove (and she absolutely did). Her story could have been like that of Officer Hops, but instead with the change in backstory was just another character flushed out in this poor adaption. I'm not hating on the actors themselves, they all did relatively well with the material they were presented with. I just think the film Artemis Fowl is a perfect example of why you should stick closer to the source material. Even though the release was meant for just Disney Plus and not theaters, doesn't mean the movie could not have easily been a critically acclaimed film.

I remember seeing this book series on the shelves of my school libraries growing up and I may have read some passages of the first book at one point but I was never invested the book series at all so I don't have that kind of attachment to them. But judging the movie here as an actual film, it is just flat-out terrible. It is so hollow, bland and erratically assembled! None of the characters have depth, any remote level of drama in the story is inept or forced, and so much of the plot is jumbled nonsense where one scene will immediately contradict the other. On a more technical level, this has some of the worst editing I have ever seen! A example being how one character will be in a room reading a book in the early evening and within less than 10 seconds is suddenly hiding in the forest at night in camouflage without even a a few shots transitioning that shows the character going from locale to the next. The "action-scenes" move way too fast or just look poorly-staged, on top that is some very atrocious CG creature effects. 


That is a shame because the only positive I can find in this shit-show, aside from a couple fleetingly humorous moments, is the decent visual appeal of the underground fairy world. The fairies themselves are a sort of militarized version of the high-tech Elves from "The Santa Clause", which is at least fine if not still derivative. And there were some bits of the cinematography and Patrick Doyle's musical score that I liked; which is the least you can expect from the usual boisterous Kenneth Branagh production. But the biggest sin is not the wildly uneven filmmaking on display, not the insanely expository script or the painfully chaotic set-pieces but it is the movie as an "book to film" adaptation. Having not read the books, I did a wee bit of research after watching the movie to see what the books were all about and I can see why the fans of the books HATE this movie! As an adaptation, it is really an abomination; a heartbreaking failure that ruins the edgy appeal that made the source material incredibly unique and compelling, all to be neutered by a committee of execs. It was streamlined in order to appeal to an "ADHD" audience that become increasingly bombarded with media content and hoping they would like it enough to spawn a franchise. Don't let my score fool you because the movie pulled one decent pebble out a mangled bucket of flaming shit that is this "movie". - 2/10 (D-)

For some context, although I could complain at length about all the issues, at the end of the day the reason this is terrible is because it's Artemis Fowl AU fanfiction. Artemis Fowl, whose main driving character trait is that, in the absence of his parents' oversight, is running the Fowl family criminal organization on his own, in the movie, says, "my father is not a criminal" and that was the moment I stepped away. Everything else built up to this crystallizing moment where it became obvious that what the movie was doing was taking the names and some character traits of Artemis Fowl and slapping it on the story they wanted to tell. This has all the narrative integrity of a Lord of the Rings fanfiction where Aragorn is a barista in a London coffee shop.

This movie's classification as a "Crime" film is only accurate in the sense that it is a crime against film-making. Artemis Fowl is a horribly acted, horrendously written, and poorly edited disaster of a film.

The main motivation of the film's title character only becomes relevant to the audience and plot almost an hour into this movie's pitiful 90 minute run-time. The characters have little to no emotional investment in each other, making it impossible for a conscious audience member to care about anything that happens on screen. This film clearly did not have a script doctor, because any competent one would have fixed the glaring holes in this cavernous vacuum of originality and charm Disney pawned off as a screenplay in under a week. The editing and pacing is horrible, there are several glaring continuity errors and the title character must have studied under Hayden Christensen's "Anakin Skywalker School of Acting" for this, his debut role. 

Don't even consider turning on Artemis Fowl, you will be worse off for watching this absolute disaster.

I decided to watch this based off of childhood nostalgia, having read these books as a kid, but it's a shame that nobody in the production team seems to have done the same, beyond lifting a few lines directly. We open to Fowl surfing (the last thing you might imagine the book version of the character doing) and Josh Gad cosplaying as Hagrid with a Batman voice, and it doesn't get much better from there. Bad and/or plagiarized dialogue abounds. This film clearly had the weight of Disney's visual effects budget behind it, but apparently struggled making anything engaging beyond bright lights and loud noises. Some of the acting (particularly Shaw's) is terrible, the rules of the universe are either inconsistent or simply never established, and many of the costumes are unintentionally hilarious. Gad plays the same slightly offbeat, occasionally-fourth-wall-breaking funny man in literally every performance. Both Dench and Farrell are great performers, but both have shown a penchant for terrible roles in recent years. (1.5/5)

It's been too long since I've seen a new release with the current pandemic going on now. There's plenty of other movies I want to see as well, so you may be wondering why did I see this? Well I heard this film was awful, so for some reason I decided to give it a watch. Look I heard Artemis Fowl was bad, but oh my god. This is barely even a movie and upon doing my research and seeing that this film has been in development hell for the longest time, I can see why. Kenneth Branagh directed this and he's directed movies like one of the rare good Disney remakes, Cinderella, the underrated Thor, the masterful Hamlet, and so much more. He's a very talented filmmaker and actor, and he's certainly not the problem here. I've watched a lot of his films to know this film is just a rushed, disastrous, edited to shit film that was dumped to Disney+ because it's abundantly clear that Disney was completely lost with the making of this movie. That about wraps up my intro...now lets talk about this "film".
As I stated before, this film is incredibly awful in every single way. As a franchise starter it's so rushed, uninteresting, poorly executed, and way too short. This movie is only 95 minutes long with credits so there's that.....even though the movie felt like it was at least 2 hours. There is absolutely no characterization to anyone including our main protagonist, the title character. Artemis Fowl is just.....really smart. He's better than you, he's better than me, he's our hero. Why is he so smart? Screenwriting, that's why! Josh Gad plays a big dwarf, yes you read that correctly. A big dwarf. He narrates a majority of this movie in this very deep and raspy voice that had me actually cringe. The first 10 minutes of this film is entirely narration and exposition....uninteresting exposition. I'll get back to that later. Artemis Fowl II is portrayed by Ferdia Shaw and according to IMDb, this is his first role in a movie. I really don't want to say this but I have to, his performance was awful. His face looked so stiff and locked up every time he finished his lines and he failed miserably at being dramatic in some scenes. It was honestly embarrassing to watch and again I feel awful for the kid. Just imagine being as young as he is and getting hired by Disney of all companies and this being your first project. I hope he's able to have a successful career after this because I can tell this isn't all his fault, he just wasn't given good direction which in some scenes you can tell. Colin Farrell is also in the movie and he plays Artemis Fowl I and I read that he shot his ENTIRE performance in 3 days and there's not a part of me that doesn't believe that. It's very apparent that he didn't want to be in this movie, I wouldn't want to either. Aside from every character being uninteresting, and the acting being awful, let's discuss the story. There really isn't one. Even though this film is entirely all explaining, you don't care about what's happening. It's a basic throwaway macguffen plot that we've seen numerous times with this faceless villain who's pretty funny with how over acted the character is portrayed. The faceless villain (I forgot the characters name and don't care enough to look it up) captures Artemis Fowl I for this macguffen and now Artemis Fowl II and his butler must save him. There's also a fairy subplot that's just there, with hilariously bad acting and effects. But I'll say the fairy subplot was more interesting than the main one with our title character, that being said, it was still garbage. There's also some action scenes with hilariously bad CGI trolls that had me laughing out loud. They weren't threatening, interesting, or anything! I was so distracted by how bad the CGI on them was for a $125 million dollar movie that I didn't find myself caring about anything else. The story is lackluster and uninteresting, but also super boring. We're almost halfway through the movie when the first "action scene" occurs and it wasn't good at all. The effects and action scene's were filmed and edited to absolute shit. Holy crap, these scenes were so awful to look at and it was again, embarrassing with the way they were shot and edited. The editing and pacing in this movie as a whole is just garbage. Everything about this movie felt amateur in every way. There's even a sequel set up at the end.....LOL. 
Before theaters shut down this year, I had watched some true crap like Brahms: The Boy 2, The Turning, Dolittle, The Grudge, and Fantasy Island. All of those movies are steaming piles of trash, but even in Fantasy Island was I able to reach in one thing I thought was actually somewhat praiseworthy in that movie. Same with Dolittle and even The Turning where nothing happens, there's even a suspenseful scene or two in that film. As for this one, there is nothing. I mean absolutely nothing I liked about it. I'm sure the books that this is based off of, primarily the first, are pretty good. About those books, if you're a fan of them, you will probably HATE this. They should've gutted this movie and started a fresh production because looking back at the first teaser trailer that was released over a year ago, there were maybe 2-3 shots in that entire teaser that were in the movie we got. It is THAT jumbled and messy. There's nothing more for me to say about this movie other than the fact that it earned the title of worst movie of the year so far for me. Artemis Fowl without a doubt, gets an F.

Be thankful this avoided theaters.  So meet Artemis Fowl (Ferdia Shaw).  He is the son of a criminal mastermind (Colin Farrell) and hopes to carry on the namesake.  When his father gets kidnapped, he must work with some friends to track down a magical acorn that will help to get him out... I don't know, your guess is as good as mine on this.  Now look, there's no beating around the bush on this one: if you have seen a trailer for this, then you know how bad this had the potential to be.  I realize that the novels to this are beloved, and I can't speak to them, as I have never found the time to take them in.  I can only speak to my experience with this movie, so I can say that Artemis Fowl as a film is an egregious Harry Potter knockoff that makes Percy Jackson look like an award contender.  Now I'm going to be candid with you on this: I can't tell you what was going on with the story in this.  Even after thirty minutes had passed, I was confused about what was happening or what direction this story was headed.  It is a bonafide mess that is just trying to get that Harry Potter money, and it is unapologetic in the way that it proceeds.  Ferdia Shaw is awful in the leading role, but I can't put too much of the blame on him.  He is just a child actor, and honestly, if this movie ever got to be popular, I'm sure he would be looking at a Jake Lloyd situation in that fans would hate him to the point that he would give up acting, even though it is not necessarily all his fault.  This movie just doesn't know how to develop characters or progress the plot, which is wild to me because veteran Kenneth Branagh is in the director's chair.  The lack of vision from him is what sinks this, and everything about Artemis Fowl just feels like it is a made-by-committee studio film that needed to go back to the drawing board before principal photography even began.  This is a giant mess, and if there is only one takeaway to be had, it is that Judi Dench needs to only come out for true Oscar-caliber films.  Between this and Cats, I'm sure she wished that she booked a vacation instead of listening to her agent.  If there is a saving grace to this, it would be Lara McDonnell as this soldier.  Out of the entire cast, she is the only one who feels like she did her homework with character depth, and whenever she is onscreen, I felt like there was a glimmer of hope in the background.  It's not a lot and it is barely a consolation prize, as this screenplay is trash, and this movie is about as messy as a big-budget studio production comes.

A joyless, soulless, incomprehensible mess of a film, Artemis Fowl is set to lose Disney millions of dollars, not that a company that gigantic will even notice of course. It aims to be the stepping stone for an extended universe, but ends up looking and feeling like a prequel to a film we'll never get to see. There's a lot of potential, not to mention a lot of material to go off, but it was a bad decision to try cramming as much as physically possible into a 95-minute film. It would have been a much better idea to adapt the books into a TV series, where things don't have to happen so fast, and you can slow-drip the story and complex mythology. What we get instead is a hodgepodge of characters we never get to know and exposition we can barely follow. Characters talk about numerous things that are either never explained or never fleshed out. At one point a character mentions how something is against ‘Fairy Law'. How does Fairy Law that work? How is it enforced? What laws are there? We don't know because the movie doesn't mention it again, it simply brought it up because it's an element of the lore. Josh Gad is the closest thing we get to an enjoyable character, but he's written as a painfully forced comic relief, who's job is to be brought into a situation and be ‘quirky', which in this film translates as ‘grating'. The acting is mostly flat, especially from our titular hero, who recites his lines as if he learned them phonetically, his voice lacking any real emotion or conviction. Much of the story revolves around magic, and the film completely fails to address or avoid the issues this presents. The Fairies are forbidden from being seen by the human. They have magic that allows them to stop time and heal people instantly, but not to make themselves invisible? It's a big, CGI-laden mess without a human touch, and I wouldn't have believed it was directed by Kenneth Branagh if his name hadn't been in the credits. It will be forgotten about pretty soon, only popping up in lists with titles like ‘Most disappointing movies' and ‘Most notorious big budget flops.' I can't say it doesn't fully deserve this fate.
